posts.name: Diego dos Santos Amaral
posts.cooked: Is it possible to control the robot through the cell phone using some version of the driverstation modified to work on android devices, or some other alternative method?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: No.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked: This used to exist back in the 2014-2015 era. I remember screwing around with it in my senior year. Not sure if such an app still exists that works with todays control system/firmware.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: It worked for a few years before randomly stopping. There was an ios app, maybe 2? if I remember correctly. Was helpful if you wanted to just dive the robot around for a quick demo without a laptop.

posts.name: Nova
posts.cooked:
If you can get Windows working on a phone… :^D

(Of course, that’s not to say you couldn’t just install linux on the phone and run it in a VM… Not the route most people are going for though xD)

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nova | Class of 2024 | Programmer & Drive Team

posts.custom_user_title: Nova | Class of 2024 | Programmer & Drive Team

posts.name: Electra Lucky Norwood
posts.cooked:
For FRC ? Not really. Froggo’s suggestion of Linux may work, but I’ve heard even using Linux for normal drive station computers for driving is frowned upon or has caused issues, so most teams avoid it (to my knowledge).

If you’re okay with a smaller robot, depending on what you are looking to use this for, look into FTC ’s older systems (before they released the Control Hub and Driver Hub.)

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: I mean, technically, Phoenix Tuner X is available for phones. But you’ll still need to enable the robot via a DriverStation in a computer to see any motor movement.

This convenient device enables your robot with out the need of your normal driver station.  Plug into your robot, Ethernet and USB port, then wait 15-45 seconds, and your robot will enable.  This is especially useful for turning on your...

Price: USD 49.00

posts.name: Koko Ed
posts.cooked: When saw this thread the first thing I thought of was the apocalyptic disaster that was Einstein 2012. Never again….

posts.name: Rethum C
posts.cooked: I can also confirm about this experience during 2014/2015. I remember seeing my old team driver showing off how he could use his phone to control the 2014 robot.

posts.name: Diego dos Santos Amaral
posts.cooked: yes, I searched for some forums from 2014 and 2015. I installed the apk of these apps, but I didn’t get control of the robot as a driverstation. Through the flashing light bulb I see that I can enable and disable the robot, but nothing more than that, a shame

posts.name: Diego dos Santos Amaral
posts.cooked: Wow, what happened?

posts.name: Koko Ed
posts.cooked: A college mentor on one of the Einstein finalist used his Samsung Galaxy 3 to shut down opposing robots amongst the other crazy things that went on that day (F4 tornados in the neighborhood. Hail smashing on the roof. Drunken baseball fans running onto the field. Insane connectivity issues. It was bad.

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked: This is not something I have seen before… does it just spoof the “DS_ENABLE” packet its expecting from the DS ? That seems… possibly unsafe.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: The best alternative would be to buy something like a Steam Deck or some other pc with a built-in controller. At our demos we use a Steam Deck to control our show bot Billy since he only needs one driver and normally goes far from the competition bot’s driverstation.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
The Asus ROG Ally might be better for teams as it’s natively windows for DS , slightly cheaper and weighs less while holding it all day for demos.

I’ve used both for controlling NON- FRC robots for work and personal projects. When I was using ROS based robots the steam deck did work, but it was still better to use a VM on the ROG Ally for Linux on windows and run my robot control software there. The Steam decks default OS was painful

posts.name: Peter Cooper Jr.
posts.cooked:
Owen_Busler:

This is not something I have seen before… does it just spoof the “DS_ENABLE” packet its expecting from the DS ?

I mean, you can even send the enable packet from the RIO itself , so I’d imagine someone could hack together something to do it from a phone.

Owen_Busler:

That seems… possibly unsafe.

Quite possibly!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
I replaced the SSD on my Steam Deck so I just installed Windows on the old one and swap them when needed.

I haven’t looked into anything else since I’ve had a Steam Deck since they first came out, but I will look into getting an Ally or one of Ayaneo’s products for the team.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: If I remember correctly, this program worked better with the crio and not the rio driver stations? (Could be wrong) I know around like 2016 the app stopped being able to work, so maybe something changed in rio firmware that stopped it. You could try with a 2013-2015 robot and possibly have success.

posts.name: Jill
posts.cooked:
If you’re okay with a smaller robot, depending on what you are looking to use this for, look into FTC ’s older systems (before they released the Control Hub and Driver Hub.)

It doesn’t have to be FTC scale and it doesn’t have to be older FTC technology. Depending on your definition of “controlled by a phone”. I think phone+controller counts?

FRC robots can be controlled via the current FTC Control/Expansion Hubs, it’s just that CAN isn’t a possibility (afaik), so you have to use PWM for everything. (This works best for simple robots).

But, it means the driver just needs either an android phone (or driver hub) + a controller, which is a perfect fit for demos.

We’ve done this to our 2020 robot and being able to just stick the drivers station phone in your pocket while driving around is quite convenient.

One messy wiring job, but functional: PXL_20240422_151623909 1920×2550 705 KB
